facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 125 of 1961 filed by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated January 20, 1961 in Criminal Revision No. 1274 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 125 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 20, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1274 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s.47(a) of the Excise Act by Judicial Magistrate First Class, Patna, with rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: affirming the conviction of the appellant under s. 47  a  of the Excise Act and the sentences of rigorous imprisonment for one year and of fine amounting to Rs. 2,000 awarded by the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Patna,

facts.text: Patna High Court affirmed the conviction and sentence of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment of the Patna High -Court affirming the conviction of the appellant under s. 47  a  of the Excise Act

facts.text: On August 3, 1957, at 10.00 p.m., motor car No. WBC 562 stopped by Excise Inspector R.R.P. Sinha (P.W.1) on Bayley Road near New Secretariat, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us by Mr. Chari that on August 3, 1957, a motor car bearing No. WBC 562 was stopped by the Excise Inspector, R.R.P. Sinha  P.W.1  on the Bayley Road, near the New Secretariat, Patna, at 10.00 p.m.

facts.text: Car WBC 562 belongs to appellant's brother Radhey Shyam.

anchor.surface_text: The car belongs to the appellants brother Radhey Shyam but he was not at that moment in the car.

facts.text: Car driven by Jagdish Sah, appellant sitting by his side, four other persons on back seat.

anchor.surface_text: The car was then being driven by Jagdish Sah and the appellant was sitting by his -side. Four other persons were sitting on the back seat.

facts.text: Car searched in presence of witnesses Debendra Prasad Singh (PW2), Paresh Nath Prasad Singh (PW3), Rabindra Prasad Singh (PW4).

anchor.surface_text: The Excise Inspector searched the car in the presence of three witnesses Debendra Prasad Singh  P.W. 2 , Paresh Nath Prasad Singh  P.W. 3  and Rabindra Prasad Singh W. 4  and recovered

facts.text: Five bundles of non-duty paid Nepali Ganja recovered from the car: four from luggage boot, one from leg space in front of front seat.

anchor.surface_text: from the car five bundles of non-duty paid Nepali Ganja. According to the prosecution four of them were recovered from the luggage boot of the. car while one was recovered from the leg space in front of the front seat of the car.

facts.text: Appellant produced keys with which luggage boot was opened.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, the appellant produced the keys with which the luggage boot was opened.

facts.text: Seizure memo Ex.2 made, statements of all persons in car recorded, including appellant's statement Ex.3.

anchor.surface_text: The Excise Inspector made a seizure memo Ex. 2 and recorded the statements of all the persons who were in the car, including the appellant. Exhibit 3 is the statement of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant claims no ganja was carried or seized from the car.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, however, no ganja was carried in the car and therefore, none was seized from the car

facts.text: All persons in car including appellant and Radhey Shyam tried before Judicial Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: After the investigation was completed all the persons who were in the car at that time including the appellant and Radhey Shyam, the brother of the appellant, were put up-for trial before the Judicial Magistrate.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate convicted all, Sessions Judge acquitted all except appellant.

anchor.surface_text: He convicted all of them but in appeal the Sessions judge, Patna, acquitted all except the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: not traveling in car, at house of Kanhai Singh (DW1) in Subjibagh Mohalla, Patna; arrested by Excise Inspector at 6.00 a.m. on August 4.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants defence was that he was not traveling in the car at the relevant moment and that he was at that time in the house of Kanhai Singh  D. W. 1  which is situate in Subjibagh Mohalla of Patna where he was arrested by the Excise Inspector at 6.00 on the morning of August 4.

facts.text: Appellant claims after arrest, subjected to threats, abuses, assault, signature taken on blank paper.

anchor.surface_text: His defence further is that after his arrest R. R. P. Sinha, P. W. I and other officers of the Excise Department took him in a jeep, subjected him to threats and abuses, assaulted him and eventually took his signature on a blank paper.

facts.text: All courts accepted prosecution evidence that appellant was in the car when stopped.

anchor.surface_text: In view, however, of the fact that all the courts have accepted the evidence of the prosecution witnesses which establishes the fact that the appellant was actually in the car when it was stopped by the Excise Inspector,

facts.text: Bunch of keys Ex.2 series from appellant's pocket, Ex.1 series from driver Jagdish Sah; keys could open luggage boot lock.

anchor.surface_text: that a bunch of keys marked Ex. 2 series was recovered from the pocket of the appellant and another bunch of keys marked -Ex. I series was recovered from the possession of the driver Jagdish Sah  5  that every key of Ex. I series could open the lock of the luggage boot and two keys of Ex. 2 series could also open the lock.

facts.text: Seizure memo Ex.F had material alterations and erasures.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of Ex. F would, however, show that material Alterations and erasures appear to have been made in that document by reason of which no reliance can be placed upon it.

facts.text: Confessional statement Ex.3 recorded by Excise Inspector R.R.P. Sinha during investigation.

anchor.surface_text: whether a confession made by the appellant and recorded by the Excise Inspector who was investigating the case is inadmissible by reason of the provisions of s. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Excise Inspector deemed police officer under s.78(3) Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, confession inadmissible under s.25 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus follow that an Excise Inspector or SubInspector in the State of Bihar shall be deemed to be an officer in charge of a police station

facts.text: Appeal allowed, conviction and sentence set aside by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal and set aside the conviction and sentences passed on the appellant.

facts.text: Notification No. 470-F dated January 15, 1919 empowers Excise Inspectors and Sub-Inspectors to investigate offences under Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the provisions of s. 92 of the Act it shall have effect as if enacted in the Act. It would thus follow that an Excise Inspector or SubInspector

anchor.surface_text: The State of Punjab Barkat Ram 1 , that the words Police Officer to be found in s. 25 of the Evidence Act are number to be companystrued in a narrow way but have to be companystrued in a wide and popular sense. Those words, according to this Court, are however number to be companystrued in so wide a sense as to include persons on whom only some of the powers exercised by the police are companyferred.
